Art not thou plumped with laughter my Lorrique,

div.stage: Exeunt with the body. A mark.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: All this excellent, but worthy lord,
There is an accident this instant chanced
Able to overthrow in one poor hour
As well your hopes as these assurances.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: What's that Lorrique? what can fortune do
That may divert my strain of policy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You know all Prussia take you for the son
Of beauteous Martha,

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: I they suppose me to be Otho her son,
And son to that false Duke whom I will kill
Or curse my stars

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: His star is sunk already, death and he
Have vowed an endless league of amity.

sp.speaker: Sarl.
sp.l: Had I Briareus hands, I'd strive with heaven
For executing wrath before the hour,
But wishes are in vain, he's gone.

div.stage: Enter as many as may be spared, with lights, and make a lane kneeling while Martha the Duchess like a mourner with her train passeth through.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Our son is somewhat slack as we conceive
By this delaying, while our heart is feared,
And our eyes dimmed with expectation
As are the lights of such as on the beach
With many a longing, yet a little proof
Stand waiting the return of those they love.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: His excellence no doubt hath great affairs
But his familiar friend Lorrique is come.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Kneel not Lorrique, I prithee glad my heart
With thy tongues true report of my son Otho
Whom since his princely father is deceased
I am come from oppressed with grief
In person to salute him for our Duke.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your mother like affection, and high care,
His highness doth return with duteous thanks
Desiring pardon of your excellence,
In that he did not first salute your grace:
But dismal accidents and bloody deeds,
Poisoning 'streasons, so disturb this state
Chiefly this gentle mind since the late death
Of your right princely brother Ferdinand
That like the careful captain of a band
He is compelled to be the last in field;
Yet he protests by me, and I for him:
That no soft rest shall enter his grieved eyes
Till he behold your presence, more desired
Than the large empire of the wide earth;
Only he prays that you would take your rest
For in your soft content his heart is blessed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Spread me a carpet on the humble earth:
My hand shall be the pillow to my head.
This step my bolster, and this place my bed.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your highness will take harm ▪

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, never fear.
A heart with sorrow filled sleeps anywhere ,
Will our son come tonight ?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Madam he will.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: See our train lodged, and then Lorrique attend
For captain of the guard; that wait on us,
Go all away, nobody stay with me
Except our son, come if we chance to call,
Trouble us not, god night unto you all.
sp.stage: All with doing duty depart, and she sits down having a candle by her, and reads.
sp.l: Quo fugiat mortale genm? nil denique tutum est,
Crudelis nam morsomnia falce secat?
Nil durum, nil non mortis penetrabile telis,
Omnia vi demit, mors Vio ●nesa sua.
'Tis true, the wise, the fool, the rich, the poor
The fair, and the deformed fall; their life turns
Air: the King and captain are in this alike
None hath free hold of life, but they are still
When death heaven's steward comes, tenants at will.
I lay me down, and rest in thee my trust,
If I wake never more, till all flesh rise
I sleep a happy sleep, sin in me dies.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Art sure she is asleep !

sp.speaker: Lor,
sp.l: I cannot tell, be not too hasty.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: She stirs not, she is fast.
Sleep sweet fair Duchess, for thou sleepest thy last:
Endymion's love, muffle in clouds thy face,
And all ye yellow tapers of the heaven
Veil your clear brightness in Cimmerian mist;
Let not one light my black deed beautify;
For with one stroke virtue and honour dies.
And yet we must not kill her in this kind:
Weapons draw blood, blood shed will plainly prove
The worthy dutchess, worthless of this death
Was murdered, and the guard are witnesses,
None entered but ourselves.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then strangle her, here is a towel fit.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Good: kneel and help, compass her neck about,
Alas poor lady thou sleepest here secure
And never dreamest of what thou shalt endure.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay, good my lord dispatch.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: What ruthless hind
Shall I wrong nature that did never compose
one of her sex so perfect? prithee stay,
Suppose we kill her thus about her neck,
Circles of purple blood will change the hue
Of this white porphyry and the red lines
Mixed with a deadly black, will tell the world
She died by violence, then 'twill be inquired
And we held ever hateful for the act.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then place beneath her nostrils this small box
Containing such a powder that hath power,
Being set on fire to suffocate each sense
Without the sight of wound, or show of wrong.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: That's excellent, fetch fire, or do not, stay:
The candle shall suffice, yet that burns dim;
And drops his waxen tears as if it mourned
To be an agent in a deed so dark.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Will you confound yourself by dotage speak,
'Swounds I'll confound her, and she linger thus.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Thou were't as good, and better, — note my words:
Run unto the top of dreadful scar,
And thence fall headlong on the under rocks,
Or set, thy breast against a cannon fired,
When iron death flies thence on flaming wings,
Or with thy shoulders, Atlas like attempt,
To bear the ruins of a falling tower,
Or swim the ocean; or run quick to hell;
(As dead assure thyself no better place)
Than once look frowning on this angel's face
Confound her? black confusion be my grave
Whisper one such word more, thou diest base slave.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I have done, I'll honour her if you command.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: She stirs, and when she wakes observe me well,
Sooth up whate'er , I say, touching prince Otho.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Prince Otho, is our son come? who's there Lorrique?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What shall I answer her?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who's that thou talkest with?

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: The most indebted servant to your grace
Of any creature underneath the moon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I prithee friend be brief, what is thy name?
I know thee not, what business hast thou here?
Art thou a messenger come from our son?
If so acquaint us with the news thou bringest.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.p: I saw your highness' son, Lorrique here knows, the last of any living.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Living? heaven help,
I trust my son has no commerce with death.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Your son no doubt is well, in blessed state.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My heart is smitten through thy answer,
Lorrique, where is thy gracious lord?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: In heaven I hope.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: True madam, he did perish in the wrack
When he came first by sea from Lubeck haven.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What false impostor then hath mocked my care?
Abused my princely brother Ferdinand?
Got his dukedom in my dead son's name?

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: I grant him an impostor, therein false
But when your highness hears the circumstance,
I know your wisdom and meek piety
Will judge him well deserving in your eyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What can be said now I have lost my son?
Or how can this base two-tongued hypocrite
Excuse concealing of his master's death.
Unhappy Martha, in thy age undone,
Robbed of a husband, cheated of a son.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Hear me with patience for that pities sake
You showed my captive body, by the tears
You shed, when my poor father dragged to death
Endured all violence at their hands:
By all the mercies poured on him and me
That like cool rain somewhat allayed the heat
Of our sad torment, and red sufferings;
Hear me but speak a little to repay
with gratitude the favours I received.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Art thou the luckless son of that sad man
Lord of Burtholme some time admiral?

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: I was his only son, whom you set free,
Therefore submissively I kneel and crave,
You would with patience hear your servant speak;

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Be brief, my swollen heart is at point to break.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: I stood upon the top of the high scar,
Where I beheld the splitted ship let in
Devouring ruin in the shape of waves,
Some got on rafts, but were as soon cast off
As they wear seated; many strid the mast,
But the sea's working was so violent,
That nothing could preserve them from their fury,
They did and were entombed in the deep.
Except some two the surges washed ashore
Prince Charles being one, who on Lorrique's back
Hung with clasped hands, that never could unfold,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why not as well as he Lorrique doth live,
Or how was he found clasped upon his back
Except he had had life to fold his hands.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Madam, your highness errs in that conceit,
For men that die by drowning, in their death,
Hold surely what they clasp, while they have breath.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well he held me, and sunk me too.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: I'll witness, when I had recovered him
The prince's head being split against a rock
Passed all recover, Lorrique in desperate rage,
Sought sundry means to spoil his new-gained; life ▪
Exclaiming for his master: cursing heaven,
For being unjust to you, though not to him,
For robbing you of comfort in your son
O gracious lady said this grieved man
Could I but work a means to called me her grief.
Some reasonable course to keep black care
From her white bosom; I were happy then;
but knowing this, her heart will sink with woe
And I, am ranked with miserablest men,

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I gods my witness, these were my laments,
Till Hoffman being as willing, as myself;
Did for his love to you, that pitied him.
Take on him to be called by your son's name,
Which now he must refuse except your grace
Attempt his service in prince Otho's place,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If this that you protest be true, your care
Was like a long reprieve, the date worn out;
The execution of my woe is come,
And I must suffer it with patience:
Where have you laid the body of my son?

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Within the chapel of an hermitage,
Some half a mile hence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll build me there a cell,
Made like a tomb, till death, therein I'll dwell:
Yet for thy wrongs young man attend my words
Since neither Ferdinand, nor Saxony,
Have any heirs, to sway their several states;
I'll work what lies in me to make thee Duke,
And since thou art accepted for my son,
Attempting it only to do me good
I here adopt thee: mine Christen thee Otho,
Mine eyes are now the font, the water tears,
That do baptize thee in thy borrowed name.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: I thank your highness, and of just heaven crave
The ground I wrong you in, may turn my grave.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lights to our chamber, now our fears are past,
What we long doubted, is proved true at last.
Attend us son.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: We'll wait upon your grace.
Son, this is somewhat, this will bear the eyes
Of the rude vulgar, but this serves not me;
Dukedoms I will have them my sword shall win,
if any interposer cross my will,
But new made mother, there's another fire
Burns in this liver lust, and hot desire,
Which you must quench; must? I and shall; I know
Women will like however they say no;
And since my heart is knit unto her eyes
If she, being sanctimonious, hate my suit,
In love this course I'll take, if she deny;
Force her: true, so: si non blanditijs, vi.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Have you not found her yet?

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Not I,

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Then I believe born by her fits of rage
She has done violence to her bright fame,
And fallen upon the bosom of the Balt.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: What reason leads ye to believe it, son?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I did perceive her some half hour since
Clambering upon the steepness of the rock,
But whether up or down I could not guess
By reason of the distance.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Stand aside, she comes, let her not scape us now.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: What has she got apparel? I and rich,
Poor soul, she in her idle lunacy
Hath taken it from some house where 'twill be missed.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Let's circle her about, least spying us
She run away with wonted nimbleness,
fairest well met.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Well overtaken sir.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: What have ye here?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And you too heartily.

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.l: I am sure you know.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why that's well, I like that, that you are well and you, and you: god buy.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Nay, nay you must not go, we'll hold you now.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why that's well, done, pray come, see my house
I have a fine house now, and goodly knacks
And gay apparel; look ye here, this is brave;
And two lean porters starved for lack of meat,
Pray let go mine arms, look here they be.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: O horrid sight!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay, never start I pray; is it not like I keep
A princely house, when I have such fat porters at my gate;

sp.speaker: Sax:
sp.l: What should this mean? why in this wood
So thick, so solitary, and remote
From common road of men, should these hang thus ▪
Brother your hermitage is not far hence,
When knew you any execution here?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I never knew any, and these bones are green,
This less anatomy hath not hung long
The bigger, by the moss and dryness seems
Of more continuance.

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.l: What's on there heads?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why golden crowns, my porters shall be Kings ▪
And hide there barebones with these gay weeds.

sp.speaker: Sax
sp.l: I do remember the admiral

sp.speaker: Hoffman,
sp.l: That kept the island of Burtholme
Was by the Duke of Prussia adjudged
To have his head feared with a burning crown,
And after made a bare anatomy,
Which by his son was from the gallows stolen;

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: Ay, that same son of his, but where lives he

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: No doubt, he doth possess some cave hard by.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come, go with me, I'll show you where he dwells,
Or somebody ; I know not who it is;
Here, look, look here, here is a way goes down,
Down, down a down, heigh down, down.
I sung that song, while Lodowick slept with me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This is some cave, let's boldly enter in,
And learn the mystery of that sad sight,
Come lady, guide us in, yond know the way.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: True, that's the way, you cannot miss the path;
The way to death and black destruction
Is the wide way; nobody is now at home,
Or tarry, peradventure here comes some will tell you more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Stand close, this is Lorrique, I do not know the
Lady comes with him.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: I ha' seen that countenance.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Stand close, I pray, my heart divines,
Some strange and horrid act will be revealed.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay that's most true, a fellow with a red cap told me so
And bade me keep these clothes, and give them
To a fair lady in a mourning gown;
Let go my arms; I will not run away
I thank you now, now you shall see me stay,
By my troth I will, by my maidenhead I will.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lorrique return into the beaten path,
I asked thee for a solitary plot,
And thou hast brought me to the dismal'st grove
That ever eye beheld, no wood-nymphs here
Seek with their agile steps to outstrip the roe,
Nor doth the sun suck from the queachy plot
The rankness and the venom of the earth
It seems frequentless for the use of men:
Some basilisks, or poisonous serpent's den!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It is indeed an undelight full walk;
But if I do not err in my belief,
I think the ground, the trees, the rocks, the springs,
Have since my princely master Charles his wrack
Appeared more dismal, than they did before,
In memory of his untimeless fall.
For hereabouts, hereabouts the place,
Where his fair body lay deformed by death
Here Hoffman's son, and I embalmed him
After we had concluded to deceive
Your sacred person, and Duke Ferdinand
By causing Hoffman to assume his name.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: This is very strange.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay tarry, you shall hear all the knavery anon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And where's the chapel that you laid him in?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It's an old chapel, near the hermitage:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But was the hermit at his burial?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: No, Hoffman and I only digged the grave
Played priest and clerk, to keep his burial close?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Most admirable!

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Nay, pray you peace.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas! poor son, the soul of my delights;
Thou in thy end wert robbed of funeral rites,
None sung thy requiem, no friend closed thine eyes,
Nor laid the hallowed earth upon thy lips,
Thou wert not houselled, neither did the bells ring
Blessed peals, nor toll thy funeral knell,
Thou wontst to death, as those that sink to hell;
Where is the apparel that I bade him wear
Against the force of witches and their spells.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: We buried it with him it was his shroud,
The desert woods no fitter means allowed.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I think he lies.
Now by my troth, that gentleman smells knave.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Swear one thing to me, ere we leave this place;
whether young Hoffman did the most he might to save my son.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: By heaven it seems he did, but all was vain
The flinty rocks had cut his tender scull,
And the rough water washed away his brain.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Liar, liar, lick dish.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How now what woman's this? what men are these?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A poor maiden mistress, has a suit to you,
And 'tis a good suit, very good apparel.
Lo, here I come a-wooing my ding, ding,
Lo, here we come a suing, my darling,
Lo, here I come a praying, to bidea, bidea.
sp.p: How do you lady, well I thank God, will you buy a bargain I pray, it's fine apparel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Run my life's blood, comfort my troubled heart,
That trembles at the sight of this attire:
Lorrique, look on them, knowest thou not these clothes?
Nor the distracted bringer? prithee speak.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Ay me, accursed and damned; I know them both;
The bringer is the Austrian Lucibella

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ay, you say true, I am the very same,

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: The apparel was my lords, your princely son's.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is not sea-wet, if my son were drowned
Then why thus dry is his apparel found?

sp.speaker: Lor,
sp.l: O me accursed, oh miserable me?
Fall heaven, and hide my shame, gape earth, rise sea,
Swallow, o'erwhelm me, wherefore should I live,
The most perfidious wretch that ever breathed,
And base consenter to my dear lords death.

sp.speaker: Lu●.
sp.l: Nay, look you here, do you see these poor starved ghosts; can you tell whose they be?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas! what are they? what are you that seem
In civil habits to hide ruthless hearts;
Lorrique, what are they? what wilt thou attempt?
Help gentlemen, if ye be gentlemen,
And stay this fellow from despairing ill.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I was ordained unto perdition, stay me not;
For when ye know the mischiefs I have done,
(At least, consented to, through coward fear)
You would not stop me, if I skipped in quick
To that black, bottomless and ruthless, gulf,
Where everlasting sorrows like linked chains
Fetter the wretched in eternal night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Knavery I warrant you, tell truth and shame the
Devil my boy, do, and thou shalt have a fine thing by and by.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: I take your highness for that reverend Duchess
Late wife unto the Duke of Prussia.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: I am the wretched childless widow sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Princess hear me, and I will briefly tell
How you came childless, you brotherless,
You husbandless, and fatherless, all, all,
I'll tell you, having ended, act my fall.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: Well, forward;

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Be it so, I have deserved a greater cruelty,
To be kept living when I long to die.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I charge thee setting by all circumstance,
Thou utter what thou knowest: my heart is steel,
Nor can it suffer more than it doth feel.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then thus, prince Charles and I escaped the wrack,
Came safe ashore to this accursed plot,
Where we met Hoffman, who upon yond tree
Preserved his father's bare anatomy,
The biggest of them two were those strong bones
That acted mighty deeds.
Hoffman the son full of revenge and hate,
'Gainst every hand that wrought his father's hurt,
Yet guilded o'er his envy with fair shows,
And entertained us with as friendly terms
as falsehood could invent; and 'tis well known ▪
Bitter deceit useth the sweetest speech.
At length he took advantage, bound my lord,
And in a chain tied him to yonder rock,
While with a burning crown he feared in twain
The purple veins, strong sinews, arteries, verves,
And every cartilege about the head,
In which sad torment the mild prince fell dead.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Did Hoffman this? and thou concealest the deed?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Pardon my fear, dread madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well, go on, I am confident to hear all cruelty,
And am resolved to act some, if no hand
Will else attempt the murderers and, but mine.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Be patient; you will find associates:
For there are many murderers more behind.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What did he with the body of my son?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Buried the flesh, the bones are they that hang
Close by his fathers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let them hang a while
Hope of revenge in wrath doth make me smile.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray let him tell the rest.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This acted, Hoffman forced me to conceal
The murder of my lord, and threatened more
Than death by many torments, till I swore
To call him Otho, and say he was your son ▪
I swore and kept my oath.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O heaven.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: O devil.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay, I pray you peace.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then sent he me for you, and you he sent,
Or as I best remember, lead you on
Unto the chapel porch, where he himself
Appointed them to stay, and there you know
What happened in your wrath.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To me asleep ,
And to my harmless Lodowick in my arms.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: On on, that deed is writ among the acts of guilt:
A brother's sword a brother's life blood spilt.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Proceed, what's next? killed he not Austria?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: He did.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O villain did he kill my father?
And make my brother kill my husband too?

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Go forward.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: After all those hated murders
He taught the foolish prince in the disguise
Of a French doctor to prepare a poison,
Which was the death of princely Ferdinand:
Next plot he purposed your grace's death,
And had opposed my strength of my tears,
You had been murdered as you lay asleep .

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Let's hear no more, seek out the hated wretch,
And with due torture let his life be forced
From his despised body.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Do I pray.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: All the land will help,
And each man be a justice in this act.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well, I that never knew revenges power,
Have entertained her newly in my breast:
Determine what's to do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Even what you will; would I were with my Lodowick asleep
In the Elysian fields, where no fears dwell;
For earth appears as vile to me as hell.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Let me be prologue to your scene of wrath,
And as the Roman Catiline resolved
His doubtful followers by exhausting blood
From the live body, so draw mine, cast mine
Upon the troubled and offended earth;
Offer blood fit for an infernal sacrifice,
Wine is not poured but on celestial offerings:
Therefore I advise you
As you hope to thrive in your revenge, smite me.
That have been pander to this injury.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou meritest death indeed.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Stay judge him not, let me a little plead in his excuse,
And this one sentence serves; 'a man compelled
To evil acts, cannot be justly held
A wilful malefactor; the law still
Looks upon the deed, never on the will:
Besides although I grant the matter small
And very safe to raise a multitude,
That by their power might cease the murderer,
Yet two especial reasons cross that course:
First: many having notice of our plot,
One babbling tongue may utter out intent,
And Hoffman being warned is surely armed
Having the fort and treasure in his power,
And be his cause more than notorious ill,
He may with gold maintain it at his will
Scape us, for no doubt he's full of sleights:
Besides, revenge should have proportion,
By sly deceit he acted every wrong,
And by deceit I would have him entrapped;
Then the revenge were fit, just, and square,
And 'twould more vex him that is all composed
Of craft and subtlety to be outstripped
In his own fashion, than a hundred deaths.
Therefore by my advice pardon Lorrique
Upon condition, that he lay some plot
To intercept the other.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We are agreed.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your mercy doth all bounds of hope exceed,
And if you will repose that trust in me,
By all the protestations truth can make,
Before the sun have run his midday's course,
I will tomorrow! yield him to your hands.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Show us the means.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: The means is in the Duchess policy.
If she can smooth the murder but a while.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll turn deceit to overthrow his fraud.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then with fair words his flatteries entertain,
And when he doth importune you for love,
Desire him first to show you the first place,
Where he beheld prince Charles after the wrack
Say you have earnestly entreated me,
But I have led you in a labyrinth
Of no effect; he full of heat and lust,
Glad of occasion will no doubt alone
Conduct you to this fatal horrid cave,
Thy King by force, or fair means, to attain
His false hearts longing, and your honours stain;
But being in the height of his base pride,
The Duke, the hermit, Lodowick and myself,
Will change his pleasures into wretched
And redeemeless misery.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: The plot is good, madam, are you agreed?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To any thing however desperate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I but by your leave, lady, and lords all, what if
This knave that has been, play the knave still,
And tell tales out of school; how then?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I know not what to swear by; but no soul
Longs for the sight of endless happiness,
With more desire, than mine thirsts for his death:
By all the gods that shall give ill men life,
I am resolved chief agent in his end.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: We credit thee, join hands, and ring him round,
Kneel, on his head lay our right hands, and swear
Vengeance against Hoffman.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Vengeance, vengeance, fall
On him, or sudden death upon us all.

sp.speaker: Sax
sp.l: Come, part, we to the cave,
You to the court:
Justice dig murders grave.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay, I'll come, my wits are mine again
Now faith grows firm to punish faithless men.

div.stage: Enter Hoffman, and all the train that attended the Duchess first.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Not to be found? hell which way is she gone?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Her highness charged us to call you her son,
The mystery we know not, but we know,
You are not princely Otho of Luningberg.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: No matter what I am; tell me the way she went
With that Lorrique; speak, or by heaven
Hell shall receive you all.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Be not in raged she comes,
And with her comes trusty Lorrique.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Madam, I feared you, and my heart was sick,
With doubt some over-desperate accident
Had drawn you to the melancholy paths,
That lie within the verge of this rough scar.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your doubt was but an embryo; I indeed
Desired Lorrique to bring me to the place
Where you beheld the shipwreck of my son;
And he hath led me up and down the wood,
But never brought me to the fatal beach,

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: It were not fit you should see the sad place,
That still seems dismal since the prince's death.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Dead? is our sovereign lord the prince dead?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Inquire no more of that, I will anon
Resolve you of his fate, this time for bear,
Esteem this gentleman your lord and prince.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: We hold him so, sith you command us so.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Will you go forward, madam?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Willingly, so you will promise me to walk tomorrow
And see the earth that gently did receive
My sons wracked body from the churlish foam.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: I'll wait upon your grace, set forward there,
Tricks, and devices! longings! well 'tis good:
I'll swim to my desires, through seas of blood.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Fox you'll be taken, hunter you are fallen
Into the pit you digged; I laughed to see
How I outstrip the prince of villainy.
Hoffman for me told such a smoothing tale,
That had not this strange accident befallen
In finding of the cave; I had been held
More dear than ever, in the Duchess eyes:
But now she'll hold me hard, whate'er she say,
Yet is her word passed that she'll pardon me,
And I have wealth hoard up which I'll bear
To some strange place: rich men live anywhere .

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: What? are you gadding sir? what moves your flight?
Coin not excuses in your crouching come,
What cause have you to ●●iey and seek strange hoards
For your wealth gotten by my liberal gift?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And my desert, my lord.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Well be it your desert;
But what's the cause you'll fly this country?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: As I live, my lord, I have no such intent ▪
But with your leave, I was debating things,
As if it should chance thus, and thus, why then
'Twere better be far off, but otherwise
My love and life, low at your service lie.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: You are a villain damned as low as hell;
An hypocrite, a fawning hypocrite:
I know thy heart, come spaniel up, arise,
And think not with your antics and your lies
To go beyond me, you have played the slave,
Betrayed me to the Duchess, told her all,
Disappointing all my hopes with your base tongue,
O'erturned the height of my intendments,
For which I'll hurl thee from my mountain wrack,
Into the lowest cavern of pale death.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Alas my lord for bear, let me be heard.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Thou hast betrayed me, therefore never talk.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: By heaven —

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: O hell! why shouldst thou think on heaven.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Stay, and believe me, think you I am mad,
So great a foe to my own happy chance,
When things are sorted to so good an end,
That all is hid, and we held in regard:
After such horrid, and perfidious acts,
Now to betray myself; be reasonable,
And think how shallow such an act would seem
In me, chief agent in so many ills.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Thou hast a tongue as glib and smooth to lies,
As full of false inventions, and base fraud,
As prone to circumvent believing souls,
As ever heretic or traitor used,
Whose speeches are as honey, their acts gall,
Their words raise up, but their hands ruin all.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: By virtue's glorious soul.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Blasphemer peace, swear not by that thou hatest;
Virtue, and thou have no more sympathy,
Than day with night, heaven with hell.
Thou knowest, I know thy villainies excel

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why then by villainy, by blood, by sleights,
By all the horrors tortures can present,
By hell, and by revenge's purple hand
The Duchess had no conference with me,
but only a desire to see the place
That first received her son, whom she believes
The unrelenting waves and flinty rocks,
Had severed from sweet life after the wrack.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: May I believe thee?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Have I failed you yet?
Measure my former acts, and you shall find
My soul allied to yours, wholly estranged
From all I ever loved.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: No more, have done.
Thou'st won me to continue thee my friend;
But I can tell thee somewhat troubles me,
Some dreadful misadventure my soul doubts,
And I conceive it with no common thought,
But a most potent apprehension;
For it confounds imaginary sense,
Sometimes inflames my blood, another while
'Numbs all the currents that should comfort life,
And I remain as 'twere a senseless stone.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Come, come, I know the cause, you are in love,
And to be so, is to be any thing.
Do you not love the Duchess?

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why there's the matter, then, be ruled by me,
Tomorrow morning she desires to see
The shore, that first received her sea-wrecked son,
And to be unaccompanied she loves;
Except some one or two, you and I:
Now when you have her near your dismal I cave,
Force her, I dot man, make no scruple do't,
Else you shall never win her to your bed:
Do a man's part, please her before she go,
Or if you see, that she turns violent,
Shut her perpetual prisoner in that den;
Make her a Philomel, prove Tereus:
Do't, never fear it.

sp.speaker: Hoff,
sp.l: Why she will be missed.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: By whom? by fools ▪ gross, dull, thick sighted fools,
Whom every mist can blind, I'll sway them all,
With exclamation that the grieved Duchess
When she beheld the sea that drowned her son,
Stood for a while like weeping Niobe,
As if she had been stone: and when we strived
With mild persuasions to make less her woe
She madder than the wife of Athamas
Leapt suddenly into the troubled sea,
Whose surges greedy of so rich a prey,
Swallowed her up, while we in vain exclaimed
'Gainst heaven and hell, 'gainst fortune and her fate,

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: O my good villain! how I hug thy plots,
This shall be done, she's mine: run swift slow hours,
Make a short night hasten on day apace,
Rough arms wax soft soft beauty to embrace.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why so, now your fear will quickly end,

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Thou wilt not talk of this?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Will I be hanged?
Ne'er take me for a blab, you'll find me none.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: I have a neither secret, but —

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Come what is't? come, this breast is yours,
My heart's your treasury.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.p: Thou must be secret, 'tis a thing of weight concerns thee near.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Were it as near as life, come, pray speak.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Hark in thine ear, I would not have the air
Be privy to this purpose, wilt thou swear?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What? to be secret? if the least jot I tell
Let all my hopes sink suddenly to hell.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Thou hast thy wish, down villain, keep this close.

sp.speaker: Lor,
sp.l: Unthankful murderer, is this my meed?
O slave, thou'st killed thy heart in wounding mine,
This is my day, tomorrow shall be thine.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Go fool; now thou art dead, I need not fear.
Yet as thou wert my servant just and true,
I'll hide thee in the ditch: give dogs there due,
He that will prove a mercenary slave
To murder, seldom finds so good a grave,
He's gone, I can now spare him, Lorrique farewell;
Commend me to our friends thou meetest in hell:
Next plot for Mathias and old Saxony,
There ends shall finish our black tragedy.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: How little care had we to let her escape,
Especially on this so needful time,
When we are vowed to wait upon revenge.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No doubt our uncle's care will keep her safe,
Nor is she in her fits so violent
As she was wont, look where my
Uncle comes, sustaining with one hand
A dying man, and one the other side,
Fair Lucibell supports the fainting body.

div.stage: Enter Rodorique, and Lucibell leading Lorrique.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Look you here, you marvelled why I went,
Why this man drew me unto him, can you help
Him now. Hoffman has hought him too.

sp.speaker: Saz.
sp.l: Brother who is't you bring thus ash pale;
Is't not Lorrique;

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I am, and 'tis in vain to strive for longer hope.
I cannot, only be provident; I greatly fear
The murderous traitor out of mere suspect
Will plot some stratagem against the life
Of the chaste Duchess, help her what you can,
Against the violence of that wicked man.

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.l: Hast thou not told him, what we do intend?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: No, as heaven help me in my wretched end,
Be confident of that, now I must fall
Never again to rise, you know his wrongs:
Be careful princes to revenge them all.

sp.speaker: Luc,
sp.l: Well, farewell fellow, thou art now paid home
For all thy councelling in knavery,
Good lord! what very fools are very knaves!
There cunning bodies often want due graves.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Son, daughter, brother, follow my advice,
Let us no longer keep this hateful plot,
Lest we be circumvented.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: True, 'tis to put on open arms.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis now too late, we are beset
With soldiers, we must fight, and since it must be;
Let's to't valiantly.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Princes prepare not to resist your foes,
We are as firm as life unto your blood.
The Duchess Martha greets old Saxony,
Prince Mathias, Rodorick, and fair Lucibell:
To me she hath discovered the damned plots
Of that perfidious Hoffman, and hath sent
These armed soldiers, to attend on you.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: We thank her highness, but we think in vain
Both you and we attend; Lorrique lies slain
By Hoffman's sly suspicion; best be joined
To apprehend him publicly.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: There is no need, our Duchess hath apparelled
Her speech in a green livery,
She salutes him fair, but her heart
Like his actions, is attired
In red, and blew, and sable ornaments.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: But 'Tell us where they are?

sp.speaker: Lord,
sp.l: At hand she comes, with him alone her plot is,
she comes in happy time for all your good.

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.l: Cease words, use deeds
Revenge draws nigh.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Come set his body like a scarecrow,
This bush shrowded you, this you,
Stand close true soldiers, for revenge.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I: do, do, do, I pray you heartily do, stand close.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: I wonder much why you ask me for Lorrique,
What is Lorrique to you, or what to me?
I tell you he is damned, inquire no more,
His name is hatefuller than death.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Heaven! what alterations these!
Can I believe you love me as you swore,
When you are so inconstant to your friend?

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: He is no friend of mine whom you affect,
Pardon me madam, such a fury reigns
Over my boiling blood, that I envy
Any one on whom you cast an amorous eye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What grown so loving? marry heaven defend,
We shall deceive you if you dote on us,
For I have sworn to lead a widow's life,
And never more to be termed married wife.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Ay, but you must.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Must? use not force, I pray.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Yield to my love, and then with meekest words
And the most humble actions, I'll entreat
Your sacred beauty; deny me? I'll turn fire,
More wild than wrath, come then agree,
If not to marry, yet in unseen sports
To quench these lawless heats that burn in me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What my adopted son become my lover?
And make a want on minion of his mother?
Now fie upon you fie you're too obscene
if like your words, your thoughts appear unclean.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: By heaven I do not jest, go to, believe me,
'Tis well you laugh; smile on, I like this:
Say, will you yield?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: At the first? fie no.
That were an abject course, but let us walk
Into some covert, there are pretty caves,
Lucky to lovers suits, for Virgil sings;
That Dido being driven by a sharp storm
Into a Lybian cave, was there enticed
By silver-tongued Aeneas to affect;
And should you serve me so, I were undone,
Disgraced in Germany by every boor,
Who in their rhymes would jest at Martha's name
Calling her minion to her cozen son.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Fairer than Dido, or loves amorous Queen;
I know a cave, where in the bright day's eyes
Looked never but a skance through a small creek,
Or little cranny of the fretted scar;
There I have sometimes lived, there are fit seats,
To sit and chat, and coll, and kiss, and steal
Love's hidden pleasures, come, are you disposed
To venture entrance? if you be, assay,
'Tis death to quick desire, use no delay.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Virtue and modesty bids me say no,
Yet trust me Hoffman thou'rt so sweet a man,
And so beloved of me, that I must go.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: I am crowned the King of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hateful slave, thou goest to meet destruction in the cave.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: 'Sdeath who stands here?
What's that? Lorrique's pale ghost?
I am amazed: nay slave stand of:
Thy weapons sure, the prize is ours.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come forth dear friends, murder is in our powers

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Yield thee, base son of shame.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: How now what's here? am I betrayed?
By dotage, by the falsehood of a face?
O wretched fool fallen by a woman's hand
From high revenge's sphere, the bliss of souls.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Cut out the murderer's tongue.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: What do you mean?
Whom have I murdered; wherefore bind ye me;

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They are justices to punish thy bare bones,
Look with thy bloodshed eyes on these bare bones,
And tell me that which dead Lorrique confessed
Who is't thou villained that least? who wast?

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: Why Otho thy sons, and that's my fathers by him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O merciless and cruel murderer
To leave me childless.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And me husbandless.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Me brotherless. o smooth tongued hypocrite
How thou didst draw me to my brother's death.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Talk no more to him, he seeks dignity,
Reason he should receive his desperate hire,
And wear his crown made flaming hot with fire:
Bring forth the burning crown there.

div.stage: Enter a lord with the crown

sp.speaker: Hoff,
sp.l: Do old dog, thou helpest to worry my dead father
And must thou kill me too? 'tis well, 'tis fit,
I that had sworn unto my father's soul
To be revenged on Austria, Saxony,
Prussia, Luningberg, and all there heirs:
Had prospered in the downfall of some five;
Had only three to offer to the fiends,
And then must fall in love; o wretched eyes
That have betrayed my heart; be you accursed;
And as the melting drops run from my brows,
So fall they on the strings that guide your heart
Whereby their oily heat may crack them first,
I so, boil on thou foolish idle brain,
For giving entertainment to love's thoughts.
A man resolved in blood, bound by a vow
For no less vengeance, than his father's death,
Yet become amorous of his foe's wife!
O sin against all conceit! worthy this shame
And all the tortures that the world can name.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Call upon heaven, base wretch, think on thy soul.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: In charity and prayer
To no purpose without charity.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: We pardon thee, and pray for thy soul's health.

sp.speaker: Hoff.
sp.l: So do not I for yours, nor pardon you;
You killed my father, my most warlike father,
Thus as you deal by me, you did by him;
But I deserve it that have slacked revenge
Through fickle beauty, and a woman's fraud;
But hell the hope of all despairing men,
That wring the poor, and eat the people up,
As greedy beasts the harvest of their spring:
That hell, where cowards have their seats prepared ▪
And barbarous asses, such as have robbed trojans of
Reward, and punish true desert with scorned death.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
